body:
Closes #36446. Related to #36378.

Still left to do before review:
- [x] Resolve issue #36454.
- [x] Preserve [`:h lsp-restart`](https://neovim.io/doc/user/lsp.html#lsp-restart) behavior.
- [x] Verify that there are no other race conditions anywhere (for instance, when vim is closing).

Other considerations:
- Consider providing a way to change the default timeout or disable it altogether. Perhaps introducing an `opts` argument, like `vim.lsp.enable(name, enable, opts)`?
- Decide if `client.flags.exit_timeout` should be applicable for this timeout.
- ~~Decide if the 200 millisecond default is good.~~ Updated to 3000 milliseconds!

comment_data.body:
I can see that reasoning. In my experience, when a server takes a very long time to terminate, that's because it's frozen up, not because it's writing something. Perhaps it's a good idea to increase the default timeout so that it's longer, so that the likelihood of anything other than a freeze is lower.

Additionally, if you think there shouldn't be a force terminate at all by default, once I add support for passing options to `lsp.enable()`, that could allow for users being able to globally set a timeout. In that case, we could default the timeout to `false`, and allow users to opt-in to a force timeout.

comment_data.body:
If your experience is that the language server froze I think you ought to report that as a bug with the language server because that's certainly not normal behavior. On the other hand, writing out index files taking some time isn't unusual. Especially on big projects or with slow disks.

The defaults shouldn't be designed to work around servers freezing but should be suited for normal operations. That means no timeout by default.

comment_data.body:
It's also a bug for a language server to not exit swiftly when the request to terminate is received. A well-behaving server should stop indexing rather quickly after getting that message, so I'd argue that if it doesn't exit after a timeout, it's misbehaving anyway. A larger timeout (on the order of multiple seconds) is probably a good idea though, to prevent messing up any well-behaved servers which might take a bit of time to finish up.

Also, of note: If I'm not mistaken, I believe when neovim exits, it also escalates to force shutdown after a timeout. Regardless of whether it should do that by default or not, I recommend that the behavior on quit and on `lsp.enable(..., false)` is equivalent. My vote is still for force escalation, but I could definitely see setting the default the other way. I think it should be configurable though.

comment_regular_data.body: When performing an [`lsp-restart`](https://neovim.io/doc/user/lsp.html#lsp-restart), there can temporarily be two clients connected to the same buffer. I think this is fine, as one of them is actively shutting down, but it can cause behavior like doubling diagnostics if an unusually large timeout is used (e.g. `flags.exit_timeout = 5000`). I think this is reasonable, but if it's undesirable, there's definitely a case for `vim.lsp.enable(..., false)` immediately detaching the client, even if the language server only gets killed on a timeout. That might be out of scope for this change, but I would still love to hear other people's thoughts on this.
I think this is ready for review! I've done a lot of manually testing to make sure there are no buggy interactions, and I can't find any.

> Given how `vim.lsp.enable` is used for both enabling/disabling a client, I'm thinking of how it might be more of a flexible API design to introduce a new `opts` argument that would be passed to the respective enable/disable handler function.
> 
> In this case that would involve refactoring `client:stop` to take an `opts` table (with `force` as the only field for now) and then allowing `vim.lsp.enable` to forward those settings.

Do you want me to make those changes to `client:stop()` and `enable()` in this PR, or should I open a new PR with those changes after this one has been merged?

> Do you want me to make those changes to `client:stop()` and `enable()` in this PR, or should I open a new PR with those changes after this one has been merged?

I would suggest incorporating these suggesting into _this_ PR. However before you do that let me invoke @justinmk @lewis6991 @ribru17 as well to prevent further unnecessary back-and-forth ~spicy bikeshedding~.
If it would help make decisions, I'd love to draft up a possible implementation. I'm completely fine with having to rewrite some of my code as I get feedback on the direction of this PR.

I've updated the default timeout from 200ms to 3000ms after comments from @mfussenegger. They also make a good case for disabling force stopping by default, but I'm still unsure if that's the best.

Anyway, with this longer timeout, it becomes more important to fix the issue I described in [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36458#issuecomment-3505422898). I'm going to begin working on that now.

I would appreciate comments on:
- Whether there should be a timeout by default.
- [How to structure adding an `opts` argument to `lsp.enable()` and `Client:stop()`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36458#pullrequestreview-3439167015).

To unblock this, let's start by having `exit_timeout` been the authority of the default behavior, and go with the change in this PR?

Then in a followup, we can see how the `opt` approach looks? (Thank you @superatomic :)
